params.generic_share: What did you learn this year? There's only one way to find out. Try this quiz.
params.title: Race Together Quiz
params.label: Quiz:
params.sub_label: How much of what you know about race is true?

questions.value: Most people who identify themselves as African American in the United States have some European ancestors.
questions.context: The Human Genome Project, which mapped out the complete human genetic code, proved that race could not be identified in our genes.

questions.value: A new study finds many people who identify themselves as completely white also have African ancestry.
questions.context: A January 2015 study of 23andMe DNA service customers found about 5% of self-identi�ed whites living in South Carolina and Louisiana have at least 2% African ancestry.

questions.value: Which group recently surpassed Latinos as the fastest-growing group of new immigrants to the United States?
questions.context: As of July 2013, the Asian population had grown to 19.4 million, up 2.9% over 2012, while the Latino population topped 54 million, up 2.1% over 2012, the Pew Research Center notes.

questions.value: Almost 10% of blacks are new immigrants from African or Caribbean countries, especially Haiti, the Dominican Republic and Jamaica.
questions.context: Research conducted by USA TODAY shows the nation is in the midst of a 'second wave' of immigration not seen since the Ellis Island period of the 1880s-1920s, largely composed of young, non-European immigrants.

questions.value: What percent of the nation's wealth is controlled by White people?
questions.context: Despite blacks' and Latinos' gains in education and income, wealth in the United States remains concentrated among whites. Calculations vary, but researchers agree that the blacks are the least wealthy group in America.

questions.value: From 2002 to 2007, the number of black-owned businesses jumped more than 60% and the number of Latino-owned businesses jumped more than 40%.
questions.context: From 2002 to 2007, the number of black and hispanic-owned businesses increased by more than triple the national rate, according to the U.S. Census Bureau's Survey of Business Owners. Black-owned businesses continued to be one of the fastest growing segments of the U.S. economy in terms of number of businesses and total sales.

questions.value: What percent of black children live in single-parent homes?
questions.context: Everywhere you look, households are changing. Kids Count Data Center notes about 24.6 million children reside in single-parent homes, with another 3.6 million in homes where neither parent is present.

questions.value: More white children than black children live in single-parent homes.
questions.context: According to the Pew Research Center, less than half (46%) of U.S. kids younger than 18 live in a home with two married heterosexual parents in their �first marriage.

questions.value: Over the past 20 years the rates at which blacks both commit and are victims of homicide have shown sharper declines than those of whites.
questions.context: Data from the Buraeu of Justice Statistice shows that the victimization rate for blacks peaked in the early 1990's (39.4 homicides per 100,000) before falling sharply until 1999 where it stabalized at 20 homicides per 100,000. The offending rate showed a similar pattern falling form a high of 51.1 offenders per 100,000 to 24.7 per 100,000 in 2008.

questions.value: What percent of the growth in the country's working-age population between now and 2050 will consist of immigrants and their U.S.-born children?
questions.context: According to a report by the Pew Research Center, the U.S. "immigrant stock" could grow from around 76 million now to more than 160 million by 2050, at which point it would comprise an all-time high 37% of the U.S. population.
